wikitext.*:
'''Cambridge''' is a town in England, known for its '''University of Cambridge'''.

==Tolkien and Cambridge==

[[J.R.R. Tolkien]] is known to have visited Cambridge at least once in his youth, for a [[King Edward's School]] 1st XV football match against the [[Wikipedia:The Leys School|Leys School]] on [[1 November]] [[1910]].<ref>{{CG|RG}}, pp. 144-5</ref>

As a fellow of Merton College he visited the college's estates in Cambridge in September [[1947]]. These included Merton Hall and Pythagoras Hall.<ref>{{CG|I}}, p. 322</ref>

He later visited Corpus Christi College in Cambridge on a number of occasions to view the manuscript of Ancrene Wisse: September [[1948]], 11–18 August [[1952]] (see also a photograph of Tolkien at the Garden House Hotel during this period, “The Laughing Philosopher” [https://www.tolkienestate.com/life/ Tolkien Estate website]), October–November [[1952]], December [[1956]], 7 May [[1957]].<ref>{{CG|I}}, pp. 340, 387, 391, 498, 505</ref>

Between the 8 and 15 May [[1954]], Tolkien was in Cambridge as an elector for the chair of Medieval and Renaissance English, a post designed for [[C.S. Lewis]]. Although Lewis was initially reluctant to take the post, he eventually accepted.<ref>{{CG|I}}, pp. 430-2</ref>

Tolkien is recorded as having dined formally a couple of times ''[[Wikipedia:Ad eundem degree|ad eundem]]'' in Cambridge, 22 May [[1954]], 9 July [[1960]] and 23 July [[1966]];<ref>{{CG|I}}, p. 432, 560, 669</ref> less formally, he dined or stayed with individuals in Cambridge: he dined with Hugh Brogan on 20 March [[1949]] (where he fell down the stairs);<ref>{{CG|I}}, p. 347</ref> at a house with no radio 30 October [[1955]] (so he missed a discussion of his works);<ref>{{CG|I}}, p. 478</ref> staying in Cambridge at the end of July [[1960]];<ref>{{CG|I}}, p. 560</ref> and with Glyn Daniel in August [[1973]]<ref>{{CG|I}}, p. 774</ref>

In mid-May [[1961]], one of Tolkien's visits to Cambridge included a Sunday spent with a fan club at Queen's College.<ref>{{CG|I}}, p. 575</ref>
